title: Bleeding the Front Brakes, Renewing Brake Fluid

body.body: Bleeding the Front Brakes, Renewing Brake Fluid
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall, causing injury to the operator or damage to the motorcycle.
Lever adjustment D71; D74; DS4; DVY; HD6; HJ7
Note the original setting of the brake lever adjusters in order that they can be returned to the same position when the bleeding operation is complete.
Turn the span adjuster fully clockwise to set the brake lever to maximum span.
Turn the ratio adjuster to its maximum setting of 21 (21 mm).

metadata.ModelsTaxonomyLink: DS4; D74; D71; DVY; HJ7; HD6

body.body: Turn the handlebars to bring the fluid reservoir to a level position.

body.name: Bleeding the Front Brakes, Renewing Brake Fluid (abdj_2 (NN, NN2, NN3, NN4, Service Manual, Brakes).svg)

body.body: Remove the screws from the brake reservoir cover.

Ensure absolute cleanliness when adding brake fluid to the brake fluid reservoir. Do not allow moisture or debris to enter the cylinder as this will adversely affect the fluid properties. Always use fluid from a sealed container and do not use fluid from a container which has been opened for any period of time. Always check for fluid leakage around hydraulic fittings and for damage to hoses.
A dangerous riding condition leading to an accident could result if this warning is ignored.
To prevent body damage, do not spill brake fluid onto any area of the bodywork.
Carefully remove the reservoir cover taking care not to spill any fluid.
Check the condition of the sealing diaphragm for the reservoir. Replace if necessary.
Remove the rubber cap from the bleed screw on the master cylinder.
Attach a transparent tube to the bleed screw.

body.name: Bleeding the Front Brakes, Renewing Brake Fluid cexz_1

body.body: Place the other end of the tube in a suitable receptacle.
Slowly apply then slowly release pressure to the brake lever five times, maintaining pressure on the final application.

The bleed screws should only be opened by a small angle, just enough to allow system pressure to drop. When pulling the brake lever or pushing the caliper pistons in, some resistance should be felt indicating that the screw is not opened too much.
Briefly open and close the master cylinder bleed screw slightly, as per the note.
Slowly apply and slowly release pressure to the brake lever five times, maintaining pressure on the final application.
Open the bleed screw slightly to allow fluid to flow out but to still feel resistance in the brake lever.
Leave the bleed screw slightly open and slowly release the brake lever.
Slowly apply and release pressure to the brake lever five times, closing the bleed screw on the final application.
Repeat steps 8 to 14 until no more air appears in the bleed tube.
With the brake lever still under pressure, tighten the master cylinder bleed screw as specified in the Service Manual.
Fill the reservoir to the upper level with new DOT 4 fluid.
The master cylinder should always be bled last. Bleed each caliper in turn before bleeding the master cylinder.
Remove the rubber cap from the bleed nipple on the right hand caliper.
Attach a transparent tube to the bleed nipple.

body.body: Place the other end of the tube in a suitable receptacle containing new brake fluid.
Turn the handlebars to bring the fluid reservoir to a level position.

body.body: Remove the screws from the brake reservoir cover.

Ensure absolute cleanliness when adding brake fluid to the brake fluid reservoir. Do not allow moisture or debris to enter the cylinder as this will adversely affect the fluid properties. Always use fluid from a sealed container and do not use fluid from a container which has been opened for any period of time. Always check for fluid leakage around hydraulic fittings and for damage to hoses.
A dangerous riding condition leading to an accident could result if this warning is ignored.
To prevent body damage, do not spill brake fluid onto any area of the bodywork.
Carefully remove the reservoir cover taking care not to spill any fluid.
Check the condition of the sealing diaphragm for the reservoir. Replace if necessary.

Use only DOT 4 specification brake fluid as listed in the general information section of this manual. The use of brake fluids other than those DOT 4 fluids listed in the general information section may reduce the efficiency of the braking system leading to an accident.
Observe the brake fluid handling warnings given earlier in this section of the manual.

During bleeding, do not allow the fluid level to fall below the lower level mark in the reservoir. If the level is allowed to fall below this mark, air may enter the system and the sequence of bleeding must be repeated.
Slowly pull the brake lever to the handlebar and, holding the lever fully in, close the bleed nipple. Release the brake lever.
Repeat steps 8 and 9 until no more air appears in the bleed tube.

Check that the brake operates correctly. Rectify as necessary.
Warning - Brakes - Dangerous to operate with defective brakes

It is dangerous to operate the motorcycle with defective brakes; you must have your authorised Triumph dealer take remedial action before you attempt to ride the motorcycle again. Failure to take remedial action may reduce braking efficiency leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
